channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Heavy cannabis users can have badly damaged lungs for life - study
item.description: Heavy cannabis users - who are prone to destructive lung disease sometimes known as "bong lung" - can suffer irreversible lung damage, a New Zealand study suggests.

item.title: Live Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and around the world on 18 May
item.description: Police Commissioner Andrew Coster said there have been 983 breaches - 700 were related to business and 250 to mass gatherings. Follow our blog for the latest.

item.title: Government reveals $278.2m for early childhood education funding
item.description: The government has announced $278.2 million from the Budget will go towards restoring the 100 percent funding band for teacher-led ECE services. Watch live here.

item.title: Māori Party announces Mariameno Kapa-Kingi to run for Te Tai Tokerau
item.description: Kapa-Kingi says that if elected she will ensure the "billions of bedazzling dollars" announced by government reach Māori in the region.

item.title: Mangawhai ratepayer who fought sewerage scheme faces Friday deadline for $115k payment
item.description: A retired Mangawhai couple face losing their house unless they come up with $115,000 by Friday.

item.title: Ashley Bloomfield and Andrew Coster on Covid-19 and level 2 rules
item.description: There are no new cases of Covid-19 in New Zealand after the first weekend of level 2 rules.

item.title: Police 'stocktake' surveillance tech after Clearview AI facial recognition trial
item.description: The Police Commissioner has ordered a stocktake of surveillance technologies after police trialed controversial facial recognition software without consulting his office.

item.title: Observing Ramadan in lockdown
item.description: Voices - Lockdown and Ramadan make for a very unusual combination. This year, for most Muslims in New Zealand, observing the fast has been more challenging.

item.title: New Zealand population hits 5 million
item.description: New Zealand's population has topped 5 million, according to Statistics NZ.

item.title: Surge in commuters on the roads and a stress test for public transport
item.description: Despite many more workers heading into offices and about 800,000 pupils back to school, it was smooth sailing on Auckland and Wellington roads today.

item.title: Law Society says safeguards in new law will protect immigrants
item.description: The Law Society says immigrants can be reassured over new legislation after safeguards were introduced to protect them.

item.title: Rates of gun crimes and killings using guns at highest levels in a decade
item.description: New figures obtained by RNZ show last year had the highest rates of gun crime and deaths involving firearms for nearly 10 years.

item.title: Alert level 2 rules mean challenges around transport to school
item.description: With 800,000 pupils heading back to school today amid Covid-19 alert level 2, transport is set to be an issue for many.

item.title: Military veteran support scheme survey gauges public opinion
item.description: A survey is asking New Zealanders if military veterans and current service personnel should get better health care and support.

item.title: Firearms, drugs, $1m cash seized in police searches during lockdown
item.description: More than 90 people were arrested and nearly 50 firearms seized in a crackdown on organised crime during alert levels 3 and 4.

item.title: Dunedin police shut down multiple student parties at weekend
item.description: Dunedin police broke up several parties in the city's student quarter which were flouting level 2 rules on Saturday night

item.title: Cell phone tower attacks 'putting lives at risk'
item.description: The attacks - some of which have damaged the towers - is potentially putting lives at risk if it means people can't get through to 111.

item.title: Covid-19: 800,000 children return to school for first time in almost eight weeks
item.description: Teachers and principals are bracing themselves for all manner of reactions when 800,000 school children return to class today for the first time in eight weeks.
